awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Leveraging the Collective Strengths of e4usa and FIRST for Greater Impact on the Future Engineering Workforce (e4usa+FIRST)
awd_abstract_narration:
Industry demands for highly trained science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) professionals are growing at a rate not supported by current post-secondary student enrollments. Efforts have been made primarily in isolation at the pre-college level to educate and excite students about possible careers in STEM. The e4usa+FIRST project is an unprecedented effort that establishes a partnership between two existing programs - Engineering for US All (e4usa) and For Inspiration and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST) - in an effort to leverage collective strengths toward furthering the democratization of engineering education. This collaborative effort prepares teachers to educate, inform, and excite youth about careers in engineering for greater overall impact on the future engineering workforce.

The project’s overarching goal is to design and test a myriad of blended e4usa and FIRST models to be implemented within underserved communities that have been unable to offer or maintain engineering experiences at their schools. Targeting unserved communities is designed to intentionally expand the reach and impact of these two programs. The overarching goal is accompanied by four objectives: 1) establish blended e4usa+FIRST models for high schools in underserved communities, 2) prepare teachers and schools to implement an e4usa+FIRST model, 3) link teachers with mentors, universities, and industry, and 4) explore program scalability and sustainability through innovative business models and technological tools. The overall effort entails a kick-off workshop, multiple development sprints, summer professional development, academic year community of practice, mentorship, university and industry partnerships, and scalability and sustainability initiatives. Implementation will be evaluated using teacher interviews, student focus groups, classroom observations, and surveys. Additional efforts exploring mechanisms to support scalability, sustainability, and incorporation of new schools into the engineering education ecosystem are intended to increase the longevity and overall impact of the e4usa+FIRST program. This effort provides the foundation for testing the likelihood of the collaboration’s future success, specifically within underserved communities. The blended approach has the potential to contribute greatly to recruitment and retention of a more diverse future engineering workforce, while demonstrating the value of such efforts to university and industry partners. The result will be a better educated citizenship with a growing interest in engineering and engineering careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Engineering Education and Centers

por.por_cntn:
A myriad of programs have been developed and offered within the US to provide pre-college students with engineering-specific education experiences. Such initiatives are typically undertaken independent of one another and are often in competition to garner greater participation. This project was undertaken to break down existing silos between two STEM programs, Engineering For Us All (e4usa) and For Inspiration and and Recognition of Science and Technology (FIRST). e4usa is a nationwide effort to democratize engineering education through an introductory engineering course for high school students. FIRST is a well-established, not-for-profit initiative that provides informal learning robotics programs that motivate young people to pursue STEM pathways. The parallel missions of these two programs provided the impetus for this project, e4usa+FIRST, to leverage the collective strengths of each program and expand engineering access to underserved schools and marginalized populations. 

The general aim of the project was to identify potential formats for embedding both e4usa and FIRST within underserved schools to help build long-term collaborative relationships, facilitate teacher professional learning (PL), broaden participation of students from underrepresented groups in engineering, and engage universities and industry aiming for future scalability and sustainability. Specific  goals  of the project included: 1) establish blended e4usa+FIRST models for high schools in underserved communities; 2) prepare teachers and schools to implement an e4usa+FIRST model; 3)  link teachers with mentors, universities, and industry; and 4) explore program scalability and sustainability through innovative business models and technological tools. 

The project was kicked off with a design workshop, involving a variety of stakeholders (e.g., engineering teachers, FIRST team members, school administrators, e4usa team members, robotics coaches, and university and industry representatives) to collaboratively brainstorm approaches for blending e4usa and FIRST. The project team leveraged the emergent results of the workshop to develop the following implementation models to blend the e4usa and FIRST programs: 1) curricular + extracurricular 2) co-curricular + extracurricular, 3) sequential curricular, and 4) concurrent curricular.  A structure for teacher PL was developed, including a summer professional development workshop, year round community of practice, winter professional development workshop, and on-demand support.

Over the next two years, the blended e4usa+FIRST implementation models were refined with teacher feedback. The PL focus was shifted from robotics competitions to robotics and programming introduction to meet teacher needs. A collaboration was established with Worcester Polytechnic Institute, which resulted in the creation of the Experiential Robotic Platform (XRP), a new affordable and accessible classroom robotics resource. The platform has opened up avenues for future  scalability, sustainability, and overall reach of collaboration with industry. A partnership was formed with the newly established e4usa 501(c)3 to continue engaging and supporting teachers/schools in the blending effort, creating and distributing XRP kits and open-source programming resources, and exploring business model innovations for future sustainability.

Overall, the program engaged and trained a total of 19 teachers across 12 US states and territories. The team worked on a number of complementary research initiatives to assess PL, teacher’s confidence in implementing a blended e4usa+FIRST model, and student engagement in the program.  Data collected included focus groups and surveys from students and teachers as well as classroom observations from schools in proximity to the PI team. Findings suggested an increase in teacher confidence regarding engineering and robotics teaching. Primary contributors were responsive PL sessions and support structures such as the year-round peer community of practice, support from school administration, university liaisons, coaches,  project team members, and the community partners. Analysis of student data indicated that the e4usa+FIRST experience provides an anchor for students to consider engineering career pathways as they acquire an engineering knowledge base and gain engineering design self-efficacy.  This work is captured in four journal and conference articles and two workshop and webinar presentations conducted over the three year period. This project also trained students (undergraduate and  graduate) and a postdoctoral scholar in qualitative research methods under the mentorship of the PIs.

A notable outcome was the development of XRP. The XRP is addressing the cost barrier for pre-college robotics by making resources more affordable, accessible (via 3D-printing and open-source programing resources), and user-friendly than anything previously available from our partners. This pilot project made it clear that there are opportunities to combine classroom-based (engineering curricula) and extracurricular (after-school robotics programs) learning experiences to more effectively impact pre-college STEM education through combined efforts to support the development of a more robust future engineering workforce.


 

 


Last Modified: 07/22/2024
Modified by: Medha Dalal
